J10Immigrants nightmarecover storycover storyNPR correspondent Aarti Shahani tells herpersonal story from front lines of historyNPR s Aarti Shahani tells her family's immigration nightmare in Here We Are By Jessica Zack

Aarti Shahani opens the door to her Oakland home in Fruitvale with a wide smile, asks her 20-year-old nephew Akshay to please keep the noise down as he fires up a blender in the kitchen and then sits down in a comfy chair in the living room with her legs and bare feet tucked casually beneath her.

"It's 9/11 today. How fitting," she says.

It does feel like a meaningful coincidence that Shahani, NPR's technology correspondent, whose voice is familiar to public-radio listeners from her on-air interviews with Silicon Valley tech titans, is discussing her new memoir, "Here We Are: American Dreams, American Nightmares," on the 18th anniversary of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, a flash point for the United States' complicated view of immigrants.

Shahani's heartfelt, galvanizing new book charts the protracted criminal justice nightmare her own immigrant family endured after her father was arrested for mistakenly selling electronics to the infamous Cali cartel in the mid-'90s. He suffered under threat of deportation for a decade after that. Shahani's deep, personal commitment to advocating for immigrant rights was profoundly shaped by those events, as well as the unfortunate aftermath of 9/11.

"I write in my book about being on the front lines of a history that's really important to remember, and it includes aspects of post-9/11 life in America which were toxic and awful, and which we have to watch out for, like the near-immediate roundups of brown men," Shahani said. "But seeing President Obama's tweet this morning about veterans volunteering to clean up Ellis Island, I found myself thinking that this day also reminds us of the sense of unity we're capable of, the good things we find in service and in loyalty to each other."

That duality - Shahani's abiding love for an adopted country's inclusive ideals, and her scorn for those ideals being debased through policies that discriminate against immigrants and the poor - is at the heart of the provocative book she says she "ran away from writing for a number of years."

"Here We Are" begins in 1981 when 1-year-old Aarti, her two older siblings and her parents, both Indian refugees who had been displaced by the India-Pakistan-Bangladesh partition, arrive with just a few thousand dollars in teeming, multiethnic Flushing, Queens "one of the most diverse tracts of land on the planet", from Morocco, where Shahani was born, to start a new life.

Undocumented at first, the Shahanis received their green cards a few years later, but carving out a new life remained a steep uphill climb. Shahani's mother found work in a bridal sweatshop. Her father, Namdev, an introvert with a head for numbers, resigned himself to manual labor, until he was eventually able to start a wholesale electronics store with his younger brother in Manhattan.

"Utopia was so close," Shahani, 39, writes in a chapter describing how that vision fizzled in 1996, the moment she arrived home from high school she had won a scholarship to the prestigious Brearley School to find that her father and uncle had been arrested for unwittingly selling watches and calculators to Colombian drug lords.

Led astray by a lawyer who convinced him a trial would be too risky, Shahani's father pleaded guilty to money laundering and was sentenced to eight months at Rikers Island. His conviction, followed by a rapid decline in his health and spirits, transformed teenage Aarti overnight from a brainy 12th-grader focused on Model U.N. and wanting to be "supernormal" into a tenacious young activist attuned to the injustices of a broken immigration system.

Shahani spent the next 15 years doing everything she could think of - writing letters to the judge, speaking out publicly, lobbying Congress - to exonerate her father and avert his deportation. In 2002, she founded the nonprofit Families for Freedom to defend other families facing deportation.

"I spent my 20s regurgitating legal facts and talking points - 'first time, nonviolent offense, eight-month sentence, the judge said on the record he's paid an inordinate price, et cetera' - because I was campaigning to make my father stay here," Shahani said. "I had that rap down. What I had never explored was, 'What was it doing to our father-daughter relationship?'"

Her father's residency in the U.S. was secure only after he became a U.S. citizen in 2009. He died not long afterward. Shahani herself became a citizen at 21 during the year she took off from the University of Chicago to work on her dad's case.

"Here We Are" is a persuasive critique of the impossibly stacked deck against poor immigrants like Namdev Shahani who are pressured to take plea bargains Aarti Shahani's explanation of the "trial penalty" he faced is indispensable, but it's also a coming-of-age story of an ambitious, whip-smart daughter getting to know herself better as her Old World father comes into clearer view.

"It's about me exploring, how did this guy who was basically a stranger growing up become my best friend in the context of the case that destroyed his life?" Shahani said.

In conversation, Shahani is a sharp thinker and articulates with matter-of-fact candor the ins and outs of her father's prolonged legal jeopardy. But her voice slows and grows quieter when she reflects on the deeper reason she wrote the book: "I needed to give him a proper eulogy," she said. "I think that he lived an extraordinary life, but the kind of life that often goes uncelebrated."

She admits she put off the idea of writing about her family's painful past for years, out of fear of being engulfed by emotion. But in 2015, after she had transitioned to journalism and moved to the Bay Area she decided to stay in California following a three-month fellowship at KQED and started working for NPR, she decided "to report New York v. Shahani her father's case like any other assignment."

She dug into the facts and wrote a first draft over the summer of 2017, in the solitude of two separate Buddhist retreats. "It felt very, very cathartic," she said.

It also felt like a timely act of resistance to President Trump's anti-immigrant rhetoric.

"Following the 2016 election, many Americans were asking themselves, 'What am I doing for my country besides complaining?' Well, I'm a writer, and whether or not I wanted to admit it, I had become a person of some privilege, with a megaphone I never could have imagined having. How did I want to use it?"

Sharing her family's embattled immigration story "became my unique contribution at a moment when people like us, who are the essence of America, are under attack. I believe we have a president who wants to erase the fact of people like me, and it's not accurate and it's causing harm. I know I'm not alone in having a sense that we're in a historic moment where every voice counts."

Shahani said she hopes that by telling the heartbreaking details of her family's tortuous path to citizenship, she'll open readers' eyes to the fact that "while policy debates put issues into separate buckets, immigration and criminal justice, for instance, our story is proof that they're all interwoven. Working-class immigrants get caught up in these systems because of the things you don't know, can't access or can't afford."

"I hope people read Aarti's story and get a much better understanding of what immigrant families really go through, and are able to see how connected and at times arbitrary the criminal and deportation systems are," said Benita Jain, an Oakland attorney for the Immigrant Defense Project who's known Shahani since 2001.

"There's an unfairness to both of those systems that people are often not aware of unless they're inside it. Aarti's never-back-down approach, that she would cross any bridge to keep her dad here, is an inspiration."

Shahani didn't expect to be a journalist as a young girl, she wanted to be a prosecutor, but she has found an obvious talent and satisfaction chronicling Big Tech's advances and misdeeds. She has reported on Mark Zuckerberg's congressional testimony, and recently interviewed Microsoft's president, Brad Smith, on the need for regulation.

"I chose tech as a beat because it felt like a safe distance from everything I had come from," she said, "And yet it's amazing to me how some of the issues I cover come full circle, for example the protests around companies like Palantir and Google helping with tracking and surveillance tools for the government's immigration enforcement agencies."

Tech reporting also threw into relief for Shahani the "double standard of who pays the price in this country," she said. "It's just amazing to me that ousted Uber founder Travis Kalanick has not been arrested. Reporting on Uber in particular, and Facebook secondarily, has really opened my eyes to how justice works in America. If you're wealthy, at most you face civil penalties. If you're working class, you face criminal penalties."

"What impresses me most about Aarti's coverage of Silicon Valley is that even when reporting on unhuman technologies, whether big tech or small startups, she manages to always tie her stories back to people," said NPR CEO Jarl Mohn. "I didn't know her personal story when I first got to know her, but now that I do from reading her riveting book, I understand how her life experiences deepen her reporting."

Talking with Shahani, who has sharp observations about everything from the jail-to-deportation pipeline and tech industry malfeasance to the shared sense of humor that kept the Shahani family together through dark times, it's clear why she describes her outlook on America in "Here We Are" as "rage in the moment and hope in the long term."

"I think it's funny that Trump's family and mine both come from Queens," she said. "We have very different lessons from there, and I would say mine is correct. Growing up, I had the United Nations working-class style. I was constantly being exposed to people from different countries, with different accents. My parents fled the partition of India, Pakistan and Bangladesh because you had Muslims, Hindus and Sikhs killing each other. They moved into a building where those same people were exchanging milk and sugar, and babysitting for each other.

"What more can I say?"

As for Aarti's lanky nephew, Akshay, who finally took his smoothie into his room to give his aunt privacy to talk about her family's saga? He's her older brother Deepak's son, and he figures into "Here We Are" too, as an infant caught up in a dramatic residency struggle of his own after his mother kidnapped him to India - and, yes, his tenacious aunt Aarti spearheaded working with lawyers in New Jersey and London, even Interpol, to secure his return.

Akshay now lives with his proud aunt and attends college. "He's hardworking, like us," Shahani writes in her book's poignant epilogue, "Dear Dad."

"Life is just fascinating," she said. "I think if you're open to what might happen, man, things can really happen."

1 p.m. Saturday, Oct. 19. Book Passage. 51 Tamal Vista Blvd., Corte Madera. www.bookpassage.com

In conversation with Nellie Bowles. 6:30 p.m. Monday, Oct. 21. The Commonwealth Club. 110 The Embarcadero, Taube Family Auditorium, S.F. www.commonwealthclub.org

In conversation with Ezra Klein. 7:30 p.m. Thursday, Nov. 7. The Battery. 717 Battery St. S.F. www.thebatterysf.com

(48/72)2016-02-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:01:06ZLexisNexisImmigration and the National Interest Subcommittee hearing on "The Impact of High-Skilled Immigration on U.S. Workers." (48/72)

Subject: High-Skilled Immigration Impact on U.S. Workers

Witnesses: Leo Perrero, former Disney IT engineer, Longwood, Fla.; John Miano, attorney for the Washington Alliance of Technology Workers, Summit, N.J.; Mark O'Neil, chief technology officer of Jackthreads, New York, N.Y.; Hal Salzman, professor in the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy and senior faculty fellow in Rutgers University's John J. Heldrich Center for Workforce Development, New Brunswick, N.J.; Chad Sparber, associate professor of economics at Colgate University, Hamilton, N.Y.; and Ron Hira, associate professor of public policy at Howard University, Washington, D.C., testify

Location: 226 Dirksen Senate Office Building

Time: 14:30:00

Date: 2016-02-25

SESSIONS: Good afternoon, everyone. Thank you all for being here. I want everyone -- preliminarily, I want to say that everyone present to be able to watch the hearing without obstruction. If people stand up and block the view of those behind them or speak out of turn it's not fair or considerate to others, and officers will remove those individuals from the room.

Before we begin with opening statements, I want to explain how we will proceed today. We have one panel of witnesses today. I will make an opening statement followed by the opening statement from Senator Durbin. Each witness will then have five minutes for an opening statement. Following their statements, we will begin with the first round of questions in which each senator will have five minutes. After the first round, if any senator wishes to continue to ask questions, we'll have a second round of questions. With that, I'll turn to my opening statement.

I want to thank all of you for being here and for my colleague Senator Durbin and his leadership. We've had considerable agreement on this issue and I co-sponsor a bill with he and Senator Grassley that will deal positively with this subject. So the hearing will focus on the impact of high skilled immigration on U.S. workers.

Last month, Barron's reported that a financial analyst had done a study, and they expect that information technology companies will cut at least 330,000 jobs this year, news that has become all too familiar in recent years. Yet CEOs and those aligned to promote legislation continue to perpetuate the myth that there is a shortage of talented workers to fill positions in technology and other high skilled employment sectors.

Indeed, a letter sent to President Obama and congressional leaders in 2013 by number of tech companies made the assertion that, quote, "one of the biggest economic challenges facing our nation is a need for more qualified highly skilled professionals, domestic and foreign, who can create jobs and immediately contribute to our economy." Closed quote. But many of those same companies adjust cut thousands of American jobs, and they have continued to cut thousands of jobs since.

Nevertheless the claims of a shortage of workers continues. As a lobbyist for Qualcomm claimed last year, quote, "although our industry and other high-tech industries have grown exponentially, our immigration system has failed to keep pace." Closed quote.

After a few weeks later, Qualcomm announced it would cut its workforce by 15 percent, roughly 5,000 jobs. And earlier this month, it was reported that Yahoo is cutting approximately 1,500 jobs. And they're doing what businesses do, we recognize that. The question is, what about our immigration policy?

And are these corporations have spent hundreds of millions, if not billions of dollars, lobbying for bills that would bring in even more foreign workers into the United States such as the Gang of Eight Bill. And the push for high skill workers is being promoted by other legislation. So today we'll hear the fact -- the facts.

Data shows that there is no shortage of highly qualified working American professionals, nor is a shortage of American STEM college graduates every year. Science, technology, engineering, mathematics. I used to think there was. I took it as a given we had a shortage. We'll have expert testimony today that I think is supported by plethora of evidence that we don't have a shortage.

The sad reality is that not only is there not a shortage of exceptionally qualified U.S. workers, but across the country, thousands of U.S. workers are being replaced by foreign labor. The picture next to me is from Northeast Utilities, a company based in Connecticut that announced it was going to lay off employees in its IT department and to hire outside companies that used H-1B employees from abroad to provide their IT services. These U.S. workers were forced to train their foreign replacements. They weren't unqualified, they had to train their replacements. And this was all done apparently according to current law.

According to one of these workers who contacted my staff and requested to remain anonymous for fear of retaliation, quote, "the only way we can make a statement was by placing small American flags outside our cubicles and aisles gradually as we got replaced by the H-1Bs, the flags disappeared just as we did."

So the fight for changes in the law that serve the interests of American people has begun in the Senate. I'm a co-sponsor of S.2266, the H-1B and L-1 Visa Reform Act of 2015 which has been introduced by Senators Grassley and Durbin who have worked on to reform these programs. In December, I joined Senator Cruz in introducing S.2394, the American Jobs First Act of 2015, a bill that would stop the abuses we are seeing in our immigration system and protect the interest of American workers. And I've also joined with my colleague, Democratic Senator Bill Nelson from Florida, in introducing 2365, the Protecting American Jobs Act which would also, I think, fixed the problem.

So with that, I'll turn to our ranking member Senator Durbin for his opening statement.

DURBIN: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. We disagree on many issues, particularly in this area of immigration. But I believe that Senator Sessions and I are seeking and we may find common ground on this issue about H-1B visas. On those rare occasions when that occurs, we've been able to enact some good law, and I hope that this is another one of those occasions.

At the outset, let me point out the title of today's hearing is not accurate. The H-1B visa program is not a high skilled immigration program. In fact, the H-1B program is a non-immigrant visa that allows an employer to a hire temporary guest worker. Guest workers are not immigrants. Their ability to stay in the country completely depends on the employer. And therefore, they can be forced to accept low wages and bad working conditions. That's bad for guest workers and it's bad for American workers.

If a company cannot find a qualified American worker for particular job and they wish to import foreign talent, the immigrant worker should have a green card. When employees have lawful permanent residence, an employer does not have the same leverage over them that they do when they have this temporary non-immigrant worker on H-1B status.

I look around the hearing room today and I have a strong feeling of deja vu. The committee held a similar hearing a year ago. In fact three of today's witnesses were here. The reality is that Congress has been debating H-1B reform for a long time but we haven't done anything. For many years we've known and identify the problems but we have to fix them.

When most people think of H-1B visas, they think of big tech companies, Microsoft, Google, hiring top-notch computer engineers and paying them top dollar. But the reality is extremely different. In fact, the top recipients of H-1B visas are foreign outsourcing companies that use loopholes in the law to displace qualified American workers and offshore American jobs.

Congress intended the H-1B program to allow an employer to hire a skilled foreign worker in a specialized occupation when the employer could not find an American worker with needed skills and abilities. We didn't intend for foreign outsourcing firms to exploit the program to bring foreign workers to our country to be trained by talented American workers, as Senator Sessions has alluded, in order to ship ultimately American jobs overseas.

Senator Grassley and I first introduced legislation to reform the H-1B visa almost a decade ago, 2007. That same year, I worked to include many of our reforms and comprehensive immigration reform legislation. That bill was filibustered.

In 2013, I was part of the Gang of Eight, Democrats and Republicans who sat down and wrote the comprehensive immigration reform. One member of the Gang of Eight, a junior senator from Florida, fought hard to keep H-1B the reforms out of the bill. Nonetheless, we made several important changes in the program.

I offered the provision of the bill to prevent large outsourcing companies from hiring additional foreign workers. It would have prohibited companies from hiring additional H-1B and L visa holders if they employed more than 50 people and more than 50 percent of their employees and more than 50 percent of their employers were H-1B or L workers.

Under current law, employers are permitted to pay H-1B visa holders substandard wages which creates an incentive to hire foreign workers and discourages Americans from taking the job. The vice president of Tata, an Indian corporation and one of the leading foreign outsourcing firms, acknowledged this. And here's what he said about using H-1Bs to undercut American workers. Quote, "our wage per employee is 20 to 25 percent less than U.S. wages for a similar employee." The issue is that of getting workers in the U.S. on wages far lower than the local wages.

I wrote provision in the Comprehensive Immigration Reform Bill that would've discouraged companies from hiring foreign workers as a source of cheap labor by doubling the minimum wage for H-1B employees from the 17th to the 33rd percentile. And employers of large numbers of H-1B visa holders would've been required to pay at a minimum the average wage paid to workers in that occupation. That's why the chief executive of Tata, when he read my provision, said this bill was very tough on outsourcing companies. It was supposed to be.

The Senate passed our bill on a bipartisan vote, 68 to 32. The House never took it up. Since then the problem of H-1 abuse has gone -- H-1B abuse has only grown worse.

In the most recent year where data's available, foreign outsourcing companies received the majority of new H-1B visas. Follow what I'm saying here. This isn't Microsoft or Google looking for that top-notch engineer, it's a major overseas company that swallows up the H-1B visas and then hires the workers at a fee, sends them over here to work at lower than the average wage and then brings them back to compete with American companies. That is never what this program was designed to do.

Last April. I joined in a bipartisan letter with Senator Sessions, eight other senators to Departments of Justice, Labor and Homeland Security asking for an investigation of the replacement of American workers by H-1B workers. But unfortunately, because of loopholes in the existing law, this broken law, it's very difficult for these agencies to punish.

Now, two of the leading Republican presidential candidates, Mr. Trump and the junior senator from Texas, have jumped on the bandwagon and say they want H-1B be reform as well. I welcome them to the debate. Their track records raise some questions.

Mr. Trump owns companies that have sought to import at least 1,000 temporary guest workers while turning away hundreds of American workers. And in 2013, when the committee considered the Comprehensive Immigration Reform Bill, the junior senator from Texas offered an amendment to increase -- increase -- the annual cap of H-1B visas to an astronomical 325,000 per year. Last November, Chair Grassley and I reintroduced our H-1B and L-1 Visa Reform Act to end these abuses. Mr. Chairman, I thank you for co-sponsoring that bill.

Let me make one final point before my voice goes completely. Ending H-1B abuse is not the only reform that is needed to fix our broken immigration system. We have millions of undocumented immigrants in our workforce. Because they do not have legal status, they are paid below market wages and they work in unsafe conditions. This is bad for immigrant workers, but it's bad for those workers, American workers, who compete with them. We need a path to citizenship and legal status so that these workers will be paid at the prevailing wage and so that American workers are then not undercut in terms of their own wages.

I think this is a fair outcome. Senator who was chairing I'm sure disagrees. But that is something that we'll hold for another discussion. So let's say about this one, we must reform the H-1B visa program, then fix other parts of our broken immigration system. I hope this hearing is a kick-off for that effort.

SESSIONS: Thank you, Senator Durbin. I think you've summed up many of the problems with this legislation very well. And I would add that I conclude that just by the numbers themselves of foreign workers brought into the country, that's impacting adversely American workers when you look at the fact that since 2000, every job in the country has, mathematically speaking, been taken by a foreign worker. There had been no increase in American working since 2000.

So we'll have to wrestle with those issues another day. Senator Blumenthal, I know you had some -- an opening comment, and I would be pleased to hear from you now.

DURBIN: If I could ask to put Senator Leahy's record -- statement in the record too.

SESSIONS: We will make it make it a part of the record.

BLUMENTHAL: I really appreciate, Mr. Chairman, the courtesy of making a few brief opening comments. And I want to thank you for having this hearing and also mentioning the Northeast Utilities situation, which is a Connecticut situation and is extraordinarily troubling for all the reasons that you have mentioned and others.

And I want to thank Senator Durbin for his remarks. I'm a co-sponsor of his bill, along with Senator Grassley. And I'm also a sponsor of the I-Squared Bill because I believe there should be the availability of more H-1B visas. But I think there has to be stronger enforcement and an overhaul of the program to prevent the kinds of abuses that both of you have highlighted today. And I know as a former United States attorney, you share my interest in strong and effective enforcement to prevent exactly these kinds of abuses.

The Eversource situation that you mentioned, Eversource in effect took over Northeast Utilities, came to my attention because of an article in a magazine called Computerworld. And the reason that it was through that means was that a gag order was placed on the employees who were replaced by H-1B visa workers. Only because of their discussion with that reporter -- anonymously because they were under that gag order as a condition of their receiving severance -- did that kind of abuse come to my attention. And I found it shocking.

I wrote to the company. I've asked for additional information. I ask, Mr. Chairman, that my letter and their response be included in the record.

SESSIONS: We'll make it part of the record.

BLUMENTHAL: Thank you. I am going to enter into the record longer remarks. I know we want to get onto a full schedule of witnesses that we have before us, but let me just say that these programs are useful if they're used legally and legitimately. If they are, on the other hand, abused to import cheap labor and export good American jobs, I think we have a very strong bipartisan consensus that they need to be enforced more stringently and effectively so that American workers are protected. And right now, there are indications that this system is failing to fairly protect our workers in the way that it should. So thank you, Mr. Chairman.

SESSIONS: Thank you. Thank you. Will our panel please stand and I'll administer the oath. Would you raise your right hands? Do you affirm that the testimony you're about to give before this committee will be the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth, so help you God.

WITNESSES: I do.

SESSIONS: Thank you very much. I'll briefly introduce each witness before they each provide a statement to us. For reference. their full biographies are available on the committee website.

First, we have Mr. Leo Perrero, former Disney IT engineer. Mr. Perrero is a -- an IT engineer. He's had a long successful career in the information technology field, having been employed by some of the largest Fortune 500 companies. As indicated already, he was laid off by Disney and forced to train his foreign guest worker replacement. Mr. Perrero?

PERRERO: I made a change in the direction of my career because January 31, 2015 was my last day in the technology field. That day, 20 years of hard work, a bachelor's degree in information technology and n IT job for Disney were all over when my team along with hundreds of others were displaced by a less skilled foreign workforce imported into our country using the H-1B visa program.

The former Disney employees with far superior skills and knowledge were the trainers and the guest workers just entering the technology field were the trainees. This situation is far from the original intent of this program and is shocking to everybody that hears it.

I worked at Disney in Orlando in some capacity for well over 10 years and received the very highest employment performance review. Quotes included, "Leo continues to provide value to our team"; "This year Leo was instrumental"; "Leo saved the company over $10,000." And finally, "I look forward to another great year of having Leo on our team."

During the holiday season of 2014, I was sent a meeting invitation by a prominent Disney executive. With an excellent review in hand along with the company announcements of record profits, my mind buzzed with thoughts of promotion or a bonus. I walked into a small conference room with about two dozen highly respected fellow IT workers. The Disney executive made a harsh announcement to us all.

"All of you in this room will be losing your jobs in the next 90 days. Your jobs have been given over to a foreign workforce. In the meantime, you'll be training your replacements until your jobs are 100 percent transferred over to them. And if you do not cooperate, you will not receive any severance pay."

The only glimmer of hope during that meeting was the announcement that new more exciting jobs would be opening soon. However, we found out that only four people would be directly re-hired by Disney of the hundreds that were lost. I was completely silent during this meeting thinking how I was going to -- how this is going to affect my co-workers. How I was I going to break the news to my family and pay all of our expenses? I would soon be living on unemployment.

Later that same day, I clearly remember going to the local church pumpkin sale and having to tell the kids I couldn't buy any that year because my job was being turned over to a foreign worker. I started to think what kind of an American I was becoming. Was I going to become part of reinter (ph) country by taking severance pay in exchange for training my foreign placement? How many other American families would be affected by the same foreign worker that I trained?

The first part of my 90 day period was focused on capturing all that we did with our jobs. We all felt extremely humiliated when the foreign worker sat next to us and watch everything that we did. The final period of the 90 days was the most disgraceful and demoralizing as we had to watch the foreign workers completely take over our jobs and we came to grips that the upcoming Disney jobs promised didn't exist.

Then finally on January 31st of 2015, we were ordered to turn in our company badges, laptops and then ushered out the door. How can it be that everybody that hears these stories about Disney and the like from the barbers to the bankers are completely shocked, yet our lawmakers continue to evade the topic and take no action?

The reason that more effective IT workers don't come out into the public is two-fold, and that is why most lawmakers mostly hear from the tech giants and are very rarely from -- heard from the displaced American workers that -- who will disclose themselves publicly. The first reason is they're scared of finding the next IT job after being displaced when that job pool is shrinking for Americans. If they speak out, they will certainly not improve their prospects of landing the next job. But this could permanently bar them from the field when a large portion of large technology companies are exploiting these visa programs.

One of my former peers who is now working for a consulting company decided to speak out publicly. He was told he had to stop immediately since most of his clientele were large Fortune 500 companies and they use the H-1B program extensively.

The second reason that more of them don't speak out is for legal intimidation reasons from gag order signed when American workers sign severance package agreements. The American IT worker feels they're legally bound to keep that situation quiet and at most speak anonymously. I'm appearing today because I'm one of the few workers who speak out in public because I made the decision to walk away from technology.

This abuse of the H-1B visa program is not about the lack of talent here in the U.S. If our own pool of IT professionals were so incompetent, then why would companies like Disney and many others have us spend months training our replacements? And also, why would such a low ratio of U.S.STEM graduates land a STEM job?

The situation at Disney is not an anomaly. The same abuse is happening nationwide. Some quotes from IT workers that I've worked with: "I know that jobs like mine are scarce because they're filled with H-1B employees." Jeff (ph), current Disney employee.

"The big tech giants say they don't have enough skilled workers which is false. This will become a self-fulfilling prophecy as we have more students opt out of technology as they continue to recruit from developing countries." Matt (ph), former Disney employee.

"Unemployment hurts. I ran out of benefits and I have to pay for COBRA -- full COBRA insurance which is over $3,000 per month because my young daughter suffers from anxiety. Besides that, I have a mortgage, utility, schooling and job searching to pay for. As my young daughter outgrows her clothes, that is even more money." Former IBM worker.

That's all I have to say this afternoon. Thank you for listening.

SESSIONS: Thank you, Mr. Perrero, for that moving testimony. Mr. John Miano, is attorney for the Washington Alliance of Technology Workers. He is an attorney who specializes in representing Americans who've been injured by the immigration system.

Prior to becoming an attorney, he was a computer programmer. He is the current -- he is the recent office -- author of a book with Michelle Malkin about abuses in H-1B and other visa programs. Mr. Miano.

MIANO: Thank you, Chairman Sessions and members of the committee. As Senator Durbin pointed out, we were here a year ago after Southern California Edison and Disney had replaced their Americans with H-1B workers. So now nearly a year has passed and we can add to the growing list of companies that have H-1B booted Americans to include Toys 'R' Us, New York Life. Citizens Bank, Caterpillar, Catalina Marketing, SunTrust, Pasol (ph) and others where Americans are afraid to come forward. And in fact, just yesterday, we learned -- and the senator might be interested that Abbott Labs in the Chicago area has -- yesterday announced to its employees that it was canning 180 Americans and replacing them with H-1B workers.

So I worked in the computer industry for over 20 years and I saw the same kinds of things that Mr. Perrero described. And I won't repeat that -- repeat the same similar story. Rather, I'd like to focus on why the H-1B disaster is happening from a legal perspective. There are several factors at work and I'll start with the two biggest.

First, in 1998, Congress made it explicitly legal to replace Americans with H-1B workers. Under the law enacted that year, it is legal to replace an American at will with an H-1B worker unless three things happen. One, the H-1B worker is paid less than $60,000 a year; two, the H-1B worker does not have a graduate degree; and three, the employer has 15 percent of its total workforce on H-1B visas, not counting those making $60,000 a year or having graduate degrees. Unless all three of those conditions are met, it is perfectly legal to replace an American with an H-1B worker.

The law governing H-1B is so convoluted that you have to follow several levels of indirection in the code to figure this out. The person who wrote the 1998 bill went through a lot of effort to ensure that it was legal to replace Americans. So what happened at Disney is not an accident, it was clear statutory design.

The second issue is that in 2004, Congress changed the H-1B prevailing wage system to allow employers to pay these workers extremely low wages. Normally, the prevailing wage is the median wage, the 50th percentile. However, under the H-1B prevailing wage system, the normal prevailing wage is the 17th percentile, and so in most locations, a employer can legally pay an H-1B computer programmer about $20,000 a year less than the true prevailing wage for the area. And its high wage locations like Silicon Valley, it's even higher. In Silicon Valley it's about $40,000 a year difference for using H-1B.

So when you combine the two, giving the employer the ability to pay really low wages to the foreign workers with the ability to replace the American workers they already have, you get the predictable result of what we've seen at Southern California Edison, Disney and the other places. And as I've hinted at here, the major structural problem with the H-1B program is it's needlessly complicated.

No one should need a lawyer to make a guest worker visa petition, but it's not an exaggeration to say that it literally takes a lawyer to determine what the fee is for an H-1B visa in any given circumstance. And this complexity seriously hinders enforcement. Rather than giving the Department of Labor the authority to enforce the H-1B program, the statutes spell out when the Department of Labor can enforce law and when the Department of Labor can't enforce the law. And the Department of Labor inspector in general has reported to Congress every six months for the past 20 years that this system leaves the H-1B program open to abuse.

On Tuesday, talking about this hearing, I spoke with a woman who was replaced by H-1B in 1994. And she expressed frustration that it seems that all we've accomplished by, you know, hearings over the years is to publicize a fact on to ph employers that they can replace their Americans with H-1B workers and get away with it.

And finally, you know, I point out that I was on the train coming down here today, I spoke with a -- was having an email exchange with a person who's very well known in the industry. And he's urged me to, you know, point out to you that it seems that the growing consensus among tech workers at this point is that the only way this is going to get fixed is by an executive order by Pres. Trump. I would (ph) say, you know, concluded here that it should not be legal replace Americans with foreign worker ever and that the changes is long overdue. I thank you.

SESSIONS: Thank you. Next we have Mr. Mark O'Neill, chief technology officer for JackThreads. Prior to his time at JackThreads, Mr. O'Neill spent eight years as a CTO for Thrillist Media and got his start in the tech industry doing custom search engine work back in late 1990s. Mr. O'Neill.

O'NEILL: Good afternoon, Senator Sessions, members the committee. Thank you for the opportunity to address you today. My name is Mark O'Neill, I'm currently employed as the Chief Technology Officer of Jack threads, an online e-commerce retailers selling clothing to men.

I've worked at startups in the tech sector since 1999 as a developer and in management roles. In that time, I've been able to observe opportunities and challenges of our immigration system firsthand. One of the challenges in the tech sector today is the extreme difficulty of attracting qualified candidates to fill open roles.

Put simply, there seem not to be enough capable developers to keep up with the pace of innovation. Competition is so fierce that my developer starting salaries have risen by over 50 percent in the last eight years. And senior positions command compensation that meets or even exceeds that of United State Senators.

Companies must compete globally for the best talent, finding it wherever they can. CTO's like me must spend a huge amount of their time recruiting employees and large industry recruiters has sprung up to for a hefty price find and coach (ph) workers. Coding schools like General Assembly and Flatiron School, to name just two in New York City alone, crank out new developers every six weeks and still jobs go unfilled.

In my role, I try to shake every tree to find skilled employees. I've traveled to college career fairs and meet ups. Used in and out of house for recruiters. Hired remote workers. Relocated workers from across the country. And also hired through the H-1B visa program.

In my personal experience, the use of foreign workers has directly contributed to the health of my company and to our ability to offer additional jobs to Americans. One example, as with all online businesses today, JackThreads consumers are increasing not at their other desks, but interacting on phones and tablets. Creating a quality experience that allows a user to easily shop or read on a 4 inch screen is incredibly difficult and requires deep technical expertise and constant refinement.

Over two years ago though, we could not find developers to keep our iPhone app up-to-date. Finally, opposing (ph) through a recruiting service connect us this with the developer in Spain, Eduardo (ph). After he succeeded in our interviews, we began the visa process and months later, he started work with us in New York.

We continued recruiting through an expensive third-party recruiter who showed us a number of candidates in the United States. The best qualified was a Chinese citizen man Meng (ph) whom we also hired.

JackThreads is proud that today 53 percent of our revenue comes from mobile devices. This is exceptional in our industry as many companies still see lots of mobile users but aren't able to get those mobile users to purchase. Eduardo and Meng's (ph) work, has in this way, directly contributed to the growth of our revenue which has allowed us to grow faster and hire more. Because of their contributions, we employ more American workers than we otherwise would have.

If the system treats those workers unfairly, they live under the constant threat that their lives could be uprooted. The system is full of uncertainty and requires confusing renewal process. Because their visa is tied to their employer, if they lose their jobs even through no fault of their own, they have 30 days to find a new one or leave the country. This makes it harder for them to leave bad jobs and gives them less leverage in salary negotiations, not to mention adding tremendous stress to their lives.

A far fairer system would allow a worker to stay until the end of his visa, even if his employment is terminated. That said, despite the H-1B's disadvantages, foreign workers demand competitive wages. I've heard fears that immigrant workers drive down wages by accepting the same jobs to lower wage, this has not been my experience.

Information workers can get competitive pay working remotely from anywhere on the planet. If I want to attract a developer from abroad, I must pay him fairly for his work or he'll go to the competition. Indeed, I have coached H-1B workers from other employers and have seen sponsored employees hired away from my company or flung it elsewhere.

I have one team and I pay them fairly. The suggestion that I would have my employees sit together yet pay someone differently because of where he was born speaks a misunderstanding of how the marketing (ph) information economy functions. It's just not how we operate. Creating second-tier pay for certain workers would be counterproductive. Neither U.S. nor foreign-born workers would stand for it.

Now, let me address how the system appears to small business employers. F-1, J-1, H-1B, OPT, visa lotteries, I knew about none of this alphabet soup when I started. My company's been fortunate in that we've had enough success to grow to the point where we can afford lawyers that help us navigate the H-1B process. It's expensive and it takes too long, but it's a lifeline for American companies that allows employers to augment the pool of labor available in the US, filling jobs that would otherwise linger unfilled.

Still, every dollar paid to the visa process is a dollar I can't spend on more workers to build the software that powers our growth. And early-stage startups can't afford lawyers and can't wait the months for employees' visa to be worked out. So the expense, complexities and delays effectively lock small businesses out of this visa program. This amounts to a regressive tax on small enterprises and hurt small businesses that are creating jobs through renovation.

It also puts American companies at disadvantage with their global competitors. I can say with confidence that for each of the foreign-born immigrant developers that I've had the good fortune to work alongside during my career, United States economy is stronger and better off with these workers than without them. Far better for the United States to employ these talented ambitious people than to compete against them.

Let them stay, build lives here, build companies here, create jobs here. Thank you.

SESSIONS: Thank you. Thank you for your thoughts, Mr. O'Neill. And Dr. Ron Hira, an associate professor of policy, public policy at Howard University. Former neighbor (ph) research associate with Economic Policy Institute and an associate professor at Rochester Institute of Technology. He's written extensively on off shoring high skilled immigration, innovation and in the decline of the middle class. Dr. Hira.

HIRA: Thank you. Let me apologize at the beginning by saying that my throat is a little scratchy today. I want to thank Chairman Sessions, ranking member Schumer and the other distinguished members of this committee for inviting me to testify today. I will also want to acknowledge the leadership of Senators Sessions, Durbin, Grassley, Blumenthal, Cruz and Nelson for shedding light on the abuse of the H-1B L-1 and OPT visa programs. And for offering sensible solutions to improve the programs.

Last March the full committee held a hearing that spurred much-needed attention to these issues. That hearing was held in the wake of news reports of Southern -- of the Southern California Edison scandal. More than 300 American workers were not only replaced by H-1B workers, the American workers had to train their replacements.

Why did Edison replace its American workers with H-1Bs, the reason was simple. The H-1B workers were cheaper. The cost savings were $40,000 to $50,000 or 40 to 50 percent per worker. The full story couldn't be told because the displaced workers were under a gag order from Edison and were not allowed to speak publicly to this committee.

Over the past year in addition to the Southern California Edison case, a number of other cases including Disney, Northeast Utilities, the Fossil Group, Catalina Marketing, New York Life, Hertz, Toys"R"Us, and I could keep going on, were highlighted by the press. But these are only the proverbial tip of the iceberg, there are many more cases out there.

Following the hearing, 10 senators, many of whom are here, requested that the Departments of Labor and Homeland Security investigate whether Edison's use of cheaper H-1Bs is a violation of the law and regulations. The Labor Department refused to investigate without a complaint from an aggrieved worker. In the face of intimidation from gag orders and the threat of being blackballed from the industry, some brave workers stepped forward to file complaints and the department began investigating. The Labor Department recently concluded that investigation finding that no H-1B violations occurred.

I think there's some important conclusion to draw from this. That Labor Department has affirmed the following. First, American workers can legally be replaced by an H-1B worker. Second, H-1B workers can legally be paid much less than American workers. In the Edison case, it was 40 to 50 percent less.

I also want to say further we also know, one, is extraordinarily easy to pay an H-1B worker much less than American worker. Two, it is extraordinarily profitable to replace American workers with H-1B. Third, hiring H-1B workers because they are cheaper than Americans is a routine and commonplace practice.

Southern California Edison and Northeast Utilities are well-known regulated utilities. And Disney and Toys"R"Us are household names. And the contractors that hired the H-1B are Tata, Infosys, HCL and Cognizant. While they may not be known to the average American, they are leading H-1B employers.

Over the past 10 years, those four firms alone brought in nearly 100,000 H-1B workers. These firms specialize in offshore outsourcing. When they get work from customers like Disney, the goal is to ship as much of the work offshore to India and other locations as possible. Those offshore jobs are lost forever.

New stories play an important role in the public's understanding but they are no substitute for statutory and regulatory changes. First, most H-1B abuses are never reported. Why? Because companies gag American workers and if workers do speak reporters don't want to tell the same story over and over again.

Second, new stories in public shaming do nothing to alter the business models and the lure of cheap H-1B workers. The Disney story receive much attention but the workers still lost their jobs. While it was displacing its American workers, Disney earned record profits. Its stock price reach record levels. Its CEO Bob Iger received compensation of more than $40 million.

Further, Disney is a firm that meticulously guards its public image. If a company like Disney will exploit the H-1B program while under the spotlight, which company isn't exploiting that and which company won't exploit those loopholes?

While I focus on the H-1B, cheap labor is a feature and attraction of two other large guest worker programs. The L-1 and OPT. Both are being similarly exploited and need substantial changes. The L-1 has no wage rules and is routinely used by the same offshore outsourcing firms. The Tatas, the Infosys, the whip rose (ph), that exploit the H-1B program.

The Obama administration recently proposed rules on the OPT that are downright scary. A three-year unregulated work authorization with no wage roles whatsoever, OPT workers can be legally paid zero wages. And that's not an anomaly, that actually happens.

Last summer DHS secretary Jeh Johnson was asked at a house hearing about Disney. He said the Congress needs to change the law because his agency "doesn't have enough tools legally to deal with that kind of situation, the Disney situation". With April 1 and the next H-1B lottery season just weeks away, it is urgent that Congress and the administration act together immediately to fix the program. We know exactly what will happen if you fail to act, tens of thousands more American workers will be training their cheaper guest worker replacements. Thank you.

SESSIONS: ...very much, Dr. Hira. And next we will have Dr. Chad Sparber, on associate professor and chair of the economics department at Colgate University. He directs a program on economic freedom for Colgate Center for Freedom and Western Civilization, an organization promoting intellectual diversity and discourse on campus.

Professor Sparber, joined Colgate in 2006 and has been an external fellow at the Center for Research and Analysis of Migration at University College London since 2009. Dr. Sparber.

SPARBER: I want to thank Chairman Sessions, ranking member Schumer and the members of the subcommittee for inviting me to testify here today. My name is Chad Sparber, I'm an associate professor and chair of the economics department at Colgate University. The economics of immigration has been my sole field of inquiry since arriving to Colgate 10 years ago.

The tremendous amount of economics literatures found that on average highly educated immigrants increase American wages employment and productivity. There are at least two reasons for this effect. First, among highly educated workers immigrants have a comparative advantage in STEM work. Even within the science field, immigrants are more likely to earn a degree in engineering, computer science and mathematics, whereas native-born Americans are more likely to major life sciences and psychology.

What this means is that, a, immigrants and native-born Americans do not directly compete with each other for jobs in the same way that a lot of people might imagine. And, be, when foreign-born STEM workers enter the U.S. labor force, it creates an opportunity for native-born Americans to respond by doing other types of work including managerial occupations that often, though not always, pay higher wages.

Second, immigrants specialize in science and engineering work. Scientists and engineers are responsible for most of the technological progress in recent decades. Technology creates games that spill over to many sectors of the economy and is the key to generating long-term sustained economic growth.

If you accept that chain of logic, and most economists do, then you can see that immigrants are vital to the American economic growth. Quantitatively, immigrants were responsible for two thirds of the growth of the STEM workforce between 1990 and 2010. And about one third of the productivity growth of the American economy over the same period.

What this comes down to in terms of wage effects that my co-authors and I've estimated, is that the rising in foreign STEM employment between 1990 and 2010 increased inflation-adjusted wage growth rate of college-educated natives by about 3.7 percentage points. Above what it otherwise would have been. For context, that is equivalent to about one third of the college-educated wage growth during that period.

I think that these figures alone attest to the problems associated with our current limits to high skilled immigration. But there are other reasons to be concerned as well. One, we know that immigrants who come to the U.S. are very entrepreneurial and innovative. A lot of that has to do with selection bias, but even after controlling for educational attainment, immigrants are more likely than natives to start a company with more than 10 workers. Twenty five percent of high-tech companies founded between 1995 and 2005 had at least one immigrant founder. And over 40 percent of companies on Fortune 500 in 2010 were found by an immigrant or the child of an immigrant.

Number two, we know that H-1B workers increase patenting activity without crowding out natives. One way to think about it is this. A firm I have a project plan and if they don't get the workers, the foreign workers that they want, they might choose to scrap the project altogether resulting in native employment and patenting activity losses.

Three, H-1B reductions may have reduced immigrant quality as well. This has happened at the college level. The highest ability foreign students have been deterred from seeking U.S. education because U.S. labor markets are close to them after graduation. This is a problem because whatever immigration policy we put in place1 should be designed to bring the best and brightest into the country.

Four, if you believe that foreign workers are competing with Americans with in our country's borders, they are certainly competing from abroad. Many countries have immigration policies favoring skilled workers. Simply put, if those workers do not produce goods and services here, they will do so in competing countries.

Now importantly, while our work finds economic gains for the average worker and the economy as a whole, I do not mean to imply that immigration is a cost free proposition. There is an important parallel here in the case of technology. We know that in recent years technology has contributed to growing wage inequality. It boosts wages of highly educated workers that has hurt or even replaced medium to low skilled workers.

Technological development has distributional consequences. Yet very few people would advocate into (ph) technological progress. Instead, we try to think about ways to redistribute money or to invoke job retraining programs to help those displaced workers. We can think of immigration in much the same way. As some groups are negatively affected, we should develop ways to assist them.

Reduced immigration is a counterproductive, non-solution because it harms the country on average. The bottom line is that the H-1B story is inseparable from a technology story and there are only three broad policy alternatives. Allow H-1B workers into the country to produce technology here, keep skilled workers out of the country and import technology from abroad, or close our borders to both skilled workers and technology. Thank you again for the invitation to testify here today and I look forward to answering your questions.

SESSIONS: Next we have on Dr. Hal Salzman, professor at the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy and senior faculty fellow of the John J. Heldrich Center for Workforce Development at Rutgers University. His research focuses on science and engineering labor markets workplace, restructuring skill requirements and globalization of innovation, engineering and technology design.

Recently he's been writing on the science and technology policy implications of his research. Dr. Salzman.

SALZMAN; Thank you. Mr. Chairman, members the committee, thank you for inviting me to speak today on high skilled labor demanding and guest worker policy. Since the hearing last March, we've seen the chasm between evidence and policy grew wider and deeper. STEM careers are being eroded by a shortsighted IT industry exploiting guest worker programs.

Instead of developing a globally competitive and internationally integrated workforce, all evidence and events suggest the substitution of guest workers for U.S. workers is accelerating. Current programs allow firms to subvert the free market and setting wage rates. And policies deny U.S. workers, whether native or immigrant, the careers and compensation they should expect given their education and skills. Instead of using the market, firms turn to the huge congressionally created lower-priced labor pool of guest workers to staff the vast majority of IT openings.

The evidence in brief. Our colleges graduate twice the number of STEM graduates has find a job each year. Of the entire workforce, only a third of those with STEM degrees are employed in STEM jobs. The glut of scientists at the doctorate level is so great the National Institutes of Health has an $11 million alternative jobs program for the 30 to 50 percent of recent PhDs who cannot find career science employment.

Engineers are graduating sufficient numbers for nearly all hiring needs. And the exception approves the rule as petroleum engineering were graduates in short supply until industry raised wages and then the number of graduates quickly tripled. Far more than needed.

And that leaves the T of STEM, tech workers, only a third of whom have STEM degrees. Another third without any four-year degree. And most are in jobs that do not require a bachelor's level technology degrees.

So of all the STEM fields, it is only the tech firms that seem unable to find U.S. workers and seem unable or perhaps just unwilling to use the free market to recruit them. Despite claims of unmet demand, this past year IT firms offered new graduates the same salaries as in previous years. Keeping average wage levels at the 1990s level.

IT firms have a level of exclusion in hiring seldom seen in the past half-century. Some firms are over 90 percent one demographic group, discriminating against nearly all U.S. workers excluding alike those who were American by birth or by choice. Making room for these guest workers, firms announced layoffs of more workers than the total number of H-1Bs provided to the industry with a layoff rate four times the size of its share of overall employment.

Any new legislation that echoes the recent I-Squared or Skills Act will expand the supply of guest workers to levels greater than the total number of new technology jobs. That is providing enough guest workers to fill every new IT job with a reserve large enough for firms to legally substitute young guest workers for their incumbent workforce. It would increase work freezes for those with a degree in anything from psycholinguistics to air-conditioning to petroleum technician with little consideration of whether there is a demand for work or a glut of U.S. graduates.

No doubt we will be told all that these firms want is the best talent available, they just can't find it here. But that's not what the firm say in SEC (ph) statements in which firms are required by law to be truthful. Accenture states the restrictions in guest worker supply would result "newer (ph) higher minimum salary requirements and increase costs". Another firm says they would have to "replace existing offshore resources with local resources, namely U.S. workers at higher wages".

That is without the congressional discount for guest workers, the highly profitable IT industry would have to hire more U.S. workers and pay them more than guest workers. The most rigorous study of H-1B workers based on actual wage records finds H-1Bs substantially crowd out employment of other workers and lead to lower average employee wages while raising firm profits. So what has happened in the past year, there's been a rising course of industry claims of unmet demand echoed by policymakers on both sides of the aisle, from here to the White House.

At the same time, STEM workers are available in ample numbers, incumbent workers are laid off by the tens of thousands. And even our brightest young doctoral level scientists struggle to find employment in sciences, much less careers and wages that will allow them to pay off staggering educational loans. Yet the IT industry says that unlike all other STEM fields, it alone can't find workers. That our colleges do not produce enough graduates. That searching the globe for the best talent leads to finding only one specific demographic group of very young workers.

These are claims from an industry that keeps average wages at levels from the last century. Fires more people in a year than H-1B guest workers it hires. And has allowed to discriminate at hiring at levels unprecedented in half a century. All by one of the most profitable industries on the planet.

Meanwhile, the tech industry spends $15 million a month in Washington. And perhaps this is a level of lobbying necessary to drive a wedge separating policy from evidence. But ever optimistic, I hope evidence prevails. Thank you.

SESSIONS: Thank you Dr. Salzman. I know you've spent a career looking at these facts. And I believe what you say is essentially accurate. Also, I have received a number written statements from other workers like Mr. Perrero who are afraid to come forward. They worry about reprisal. They worry about having to sign an agreement or they couldn't get a severance package. And I'll offer those statements for the record without objection.

I understand that Senator Cruz and other members of the committee will be offering statements for the record also. I had to say on Mr. O'Neill, I seen no needs into -- need to end this program, but surely you would understand that people who come for (ph) a limited period of time just to take a job who will work for less or quite a different situation than an immigrant who wants to come in and start a company.

And we needed work on a legal system that would favor the most highly qualified. One way to do that is by salary. If you're paying the salary of United States senator, I think you can get a lot of workers, unless you're in a very expensive neighborhood. I got to tell you, we were blessed by the salaries we are paid. But I suspect you don't get as many vacation days as we do. Government workers.

Mr. Perrero, thank you for your very powerful testimony. It's truly saddening and heartbreaking what you and others have suffered. You noted you were one of the most respected employees in your division. Would you say that the majority of the workers whose jobs were outsourced were similar to yours? And that they were quality employees and able -- fully able to do the job that was being required of them? And --

PERRERO: Yes, they are...

SESSIONS: ...and they are to (ph) and doesn't require genius level people to fill those jobs that only can be obtained somewhere around the globe?

PERRERO: Well, we were very experienced. We were at the top of our fields. These were top-notch people. They had the top honors that the company offered to us and recognized us as such. And that's why it was such a shock to us to be pulled into this room and be told that we had 90 days to train our replacements.

SESSIONS: Well, thank you. Professor Salzman, you note that we have a -- you look with jaundiced eye towards the situation of more technically skilled workers than we have jobs. I've been shocked at the report that was published in Barron's that we would have as many as 330,000 IT workers laid off this year.

Is that consistent with your studies? And always seeing this rise in demand for IT workers? Or is it flattened out or even declining?

SALZMAN: I think you're right. The layoff announcements I've heard were 80,000 most recently from Challenger and Gray of announced layoffs. And we know that they often appear in the hundreds and tens of thousands. So we see these layoffs while they're talking for the need for more guest workers and more work is being shift offshore.

So I don't -- I don't think there's any indication that demand this increase in anywhere near what you'd expect. Or, you know, from what one industry is saying. The hiring doesn't reflect that.

SESSIONS: Professor Hira, on the college campuses, if wages aren't going up, they have increased since the late '90s and if jobs may actually be defining, could this person in a situation in which talented young people wouldn't go into these fields and creating another cycle of decline in American produced technological graduates?

HIRA: You know, so we've seen these sort of typical boom and bust cycles. And Professor Salzman talked about petroleum engineering where there aren't a lot of H-1B workers. But where we had a boom in oil prices, there is a large increase in salaries for petroleum engineering (ph). And the market reacted, the education market, students reacted by going into petroleum engineering.

Now, with the oil prices plummeted, right, there are those kinds of opportunities. And what you'll see is students and engineers will move out of those fields. This is the normal functioning of the market. When you intervene with guest worker programs, you're intervening in that normal labor market to education market signal.

And that signal, that pricing signal is very very important. People will -- students will vote with their feet. They're going to move into fields that they believe are going to be good careers. And so I think that we should be very concerned about that.

Secondly, there's another set of workers that's really important that's often overlooked. And that's the incumbent workers.
